Award.AwardTitle: UCLA Dark Matter Advanced Training Institute
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for a three-day Advanced Training Institute (ATI) for about 30 junior researchers, all already engaged in dark matter research from diverse backgrounds and subfields. The Institute will take place on Feb 18-20, 2018, immediately preceding the well-established three-day international conference on "Sources and Detection of Dark Matter and Dark Energy in the Universe," which will take place on Feb. 21-23, 2018 on the UCLA campus.

This conference is aligned with NSF interests in developing a diverse workforce. The organizers will pay particular attention to the diversity of the students and the lecturers, in particular to the participation of women and other under-represented groups.

The UCLA ATI, devoted entirely to dark matter, would significantly enhance the opportunities in the US for junior researchers on the dark matter problem to get a high-level training on forefront research issues in different subfields from the experts in each of these subfields. The hunt for the dark matter is truly an interdisciplinary enterprise that involves laboratory experiments, astrophysical and cosmological observations combined with simulations of structure formation in the Universe, searches at accelerators, such as the LHC, and particle physics theory. The ATI will cover a variety of different subjects in these areas, highlighting the most interesting advances. This award will provide partial financial support to non-local junior researchers participating in the UCLA Dark Matter Advanced Training Institute.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF support helped to finance a program for advanced graduate students working in research in any aspect of the dark matter (DM) problem, consisting of a three-day Advanced Training Institute (ATI), Feb 18 to 20, 2018  (whose website is https://conferences.pa.ucla.edu/ATI-2018/), followed by the participation of the trainees in the UCLA DM 2018 Conference, from Feb. 21 to 23, 2018 (find more about it at https://indico.cern.ch/event/653314/overview).   


This is the first time an ATI is paired with the well established international UCLA DM Conference, held every two years since 1994, which this year had about 190 participants.  The intention is to continue holding an ATI paired with each subsequent UCLA DM conference. This will  fulfill a much needed role, since no regular advance training specifically devoted to DM research exists in the US.  DM research is truly interdisciplinary, involving laboratory experiments, astrophysical and cosmological observations combined with simulations of structure formation in the Universe, searches at accelerators, and particle physics theory. Due to the interconnectivity of all the subfields and the fast pace of advance in all of them, the training of junior researchers in matters beyond the restricted questions addressed in their specific work is a must for the success of our final goal of elucidating the nature of the DM.


Pairing the ATI with the conference allowed ATI lecturers to be recruited from the specialists attending the conference and allowed  the trainees to attend the conference better prepared to understand the talks. Moreover, the trainees gained exposure for their work by presenting it at the conference (mostly as posters). The 31 trainees in the UCLA 2018 ATI were a diverse group in terms of gender (23% were women), specialty (experimentalists and theoreticians in particle physics and astrophysics/cosmology), and institutions of origin (as can be seen in https://conferences.pa.ucla.edu/ATI-2018/ati-trainees.pdf).

 
The ATI lecturers and timely subjects, chosen by the ATI Directors, G. Gelmini (UCLA), G. Fuller (UCSD) and B. Sadoulet (UCB),  were the following:  

1- Kallia Petraki (LPTHE, Paris, France) on “Theoretical aspects of DM theory”;

2- Matt Pyle (UCB) on “New experimental ideas to search for light DM”;

3- Anne Green (U. of Nottingham, UK) on “Primordial Black Holes as part of the DM” ;

4-James Bullock (UCI) on “Observation and simulations of DM in the Universe”;

5- Christoph Weniger (U. of Amsterdam, Netherlands) on “Indirect DM detection”;

6- Marcela Carena (Fermilab and U. of Chicago) on “DM searches at accelerators”. 


The slides and videos of the lectures (two per subject) and the videos of the discussion sessions held at the ATI, are  posted online (see https://conferences.pa.ucla.edu/ATI-2018/lectures.html). They constitute a useful resource not only for junior researchers but also for more senior ones trying to understand recent developments outside their subfield of research.
